citations.narrative:
The facility has not yet developed and documented a detailed contingency plan that addresses emergencies or disasters
that could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals. A
contingency plan is required to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of the
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The plan should identify the situations triggering the plan, outline the
tasks to be carried out, identify a chain of command, and address how the response and recovery will be handled. The
facility shall develop and document a detailed contingency plan. Correct by July 20, 2023.

A week prior to inspection an 8 months old, male Patagonian cavy, housed outside in a primary enclosure not enclosed
by a perimeter fence, was injured because of a dog harassing it. According to the licensee a dog entered the area of the
cavy’s primary enclosure and barked at it while running around the enclosure. The cavy, attempting to avoid the dog, ran
into the sides of its enclosure which resulted in injuries. The injuries include a laceration to its face which required sutures
from the Attending Veterinarian. A perimeter fence is necessary to keep out unauthorized animals and persons and to act
as a secondary containment fence if the animal were to get out. The facility shall build a secondary or perimeter fence for
exotic species that is at least six feet in height and three feet in distance from the primary enclosure. Correct by July 20,
2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
WILLIAM HEINE, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
